study_description: Comparative metagenomic survey of gut microbiomes from 33 mammalian species, and 18 calorie-restricted humans, addressing the role of diet in shaping microbial communitry structure and function.
study_abstract: The co-evolution of mammals and their gut microbiota reflects their joint evolution and diversity of habitats and life styles. We used shotgun sequencing of microbial community DNA and targeted sequencing of bacterial 16S rRNA genes to gain an understanding of how microbial communities adapt to extremes of diets. We sampled fecal DNAs from 33 mammalian species and 18 humans who kept detailed diet records, and found that the functional adaptation of the microbiota to diet is similar across different mammalian lineages. The differences between microbiomes of host species having different diets appears to stem from differing abundances of shared functions, for example the microbiomes of carnivores have specialized to degrade proteins as an energy source, while communities within herbivores have specialized to synthesize amino acid building blocks.  These results illustrate the value of characterizing vertebrate gut microbiomes to understand host evolutionary histories at a supra-organismal level.
study_title: Diet drives convergence in gut microbiome functions across mammalian phylogeny and within humans

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80ÃÂºC.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80C.  Wild animal feces 
were oven-dried for a minimum of 30 min at 70C immediately after collection, and 
maintained in this state until they were processed for DNA extraction.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80C.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

samp_mat_process.definition: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v1.0) terms please see http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/40832

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

samp_mat_process.definition: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v1.0) terms please see http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/40832

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

continent.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by continent.  Use one of: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80ÃÂÃÂºC.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80ÃÂºC.  Wild animal feces 
were oven-dried for a minimum of 30 min at 70ÃÂºC immediately after collection, and 
maintained in this state until they were processed for DNA extraction.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80C.  Wild animal feces 
were oven-dried for a minimum of 30 min at 70C immediately after collection, and 
maintained in this state until they were processed for DNA extraction.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80ÃÂÃÂºC.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

samp_mat_process.definition: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v1.0) terms please see http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/40832

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

isol_growth_condt.definition: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation of the sample

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

continent.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by continent.  Use one of: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

samp_collect_device.definition: The method or device employed for isolating/collecting the sample
samp_collect_device.value:
Fecal samples were collected from wild and captive animals in the early morning and immediately frozen in N2 or dry ice, shipped or returned to the laboratory on dry ice, and preserved at -80ÃÂÃÂºC.  For conspecific animals housed in groups, 2-3 samples were obtained from separate parts of their shared nighttime living quarters, to ensure that they were produced by different individuals. 
Samples from wild animals were collected in Namibia (HartmannÃÂÃÂs Mountain 
Zebra, Hamadryas Baboon, Springbok, African Elephant) by observing animals drawn to 
a water hole.

Fecal samples were pulverized with a mortar and pestle at -80oC. A 500
mg aliquot of each frozen pulverized sample was re-suspended in a solution containing
500μL of extraction buffer [200mM Tris (pH 8.0), 200mM NaCl, 20mM EDTA], 210μL
of 20% SDS, 500μL of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and 500μL of a
slurry of 0.1-mm diameter zirconia/silica beads. Cells were then mechanically disrupted
using a bead beater (Biospec, maximum setting; 3 min at room temperature), followed by
extraction with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and precipitation with isopropanol.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water
